title: Tinnitus Evaluation
icd10: D33.3 (Benign neoplasm of cranial nerves — vestibular schwannoma)
scope: ** Neurological evaluation and management of tinnitus in adults. Covers classification (pulsatile vs. non-pulsatile, subjective vs. objective), identification of red flags (unilateral tinnitus, pulsatile tinnitus, associated hearing loss, focal neurological deficits), evaluation for vascular causes (dural arteriovenous fistula, carotid stenosis/dissection, IIH, glomus tumors), cerebellopontine angle tumors (vestibular schwannoma/acoustic neuroma), audiometric evaluation, MRI/MRA indications, and management including CBT for tinnitus, sound therapy, and pharmacotherapy. Excludes primary otologic management of cerumen impaction, otitis media, otosclerosis, and cochlear implant evaluation (ENT-managed). Excludes tinnitus in pediatric populations.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Anemia can cause pulsatile tinnitus (high-output state); polycythemia (hyperviscosity); infection if otitis suspected
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; anemia (Hgb <10) — correct and reassess; elevated WBC — infection

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities; renal dysfunction (uremia can cause tinnitus); baseline metabolic assessment
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; BUN/Cr elevation — renal evaluation; hyponatremia

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hyperthyroidism causes pulsatile tinnitus (high-output state); hypothyroidism associated with sensorineural hearing loss
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyperthyroidism — endocrine referral; hypothyroidism — treat and reassess hearing

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Diabetes is risk factor for sensorineural hearing loss and small vessel disease; diabetic neuropathy affecting cochlear nerve; relevant for sudden SNHL workup
Vascular risk factor assessment if pulsatile tinnitus or vascular cause suspected; dyslipidemia associated with sensorineural hearing loss

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Temporal arteritis (pulsatile tinnitus in elderly); vasculitis; autoimmune inner ear disease
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated — evaluate for GCA in >50 yo, autoimmune SNHL

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Autoimmune inner ear disease (AIED); systemic lupus; vasculitis affecting cochlea
Otosyphilis can present as tinnitus and hearing loss; especially if bilateral asymmetric SNHL
B12 deficiency associated with tinnitus and sensorineural hearing loss
Iron deficiency anemia is common cause of pulsatile tinnitus (high-output state); even without frank anemia
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Ferritin >50; iron-deficient — supplementation; pulsatile tinnitus may resolve

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Zinc deficiency has been associated with tinnitus in some studies; cochlear function
If cerebral venous sinus thrombosis suspected (pulsatile tinnitus, headache, papilledema)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Confirmatory for syphilis if RPR positive; otosyphilis diagnosis
Lyme neuroborreliosis can cause cranial neuropathies and hearing loss in endemic areas
Autoimmune inner ear disease if bilateral progressive SNHL with tinnitus; responds to steroids
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; positive — steroid trial for AIED

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Rare; paraneoplastic cochlear/vestibular degeneration; anti-Hu, anti-CRMP5
If IIH suspected (opening pressure); infectious/inflammatory cause; leptomeningeal disease; neurosyphilis confirmation
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Opening pressure >25 cm H2O — IIH; pleocytosis — infection/inflammation; positive VDRL — neurosyphilis

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If cerebral venous thrombosis suspected as cause of pulsatile tinnitus

Lumbar Puncture.timing: **Indicated if IIH suspected**: Pulsatile tinnitus + headache + papilledema (especially in young obese female); also if CSF infection or leptomeningeal disease suspected; **Measure opening pressure** in lateral decubitus position
Lumbar Puncture.target: Opening pressure >25 cm H2O — IIH; normal CSF composition in IIH; pleocytosis — infection; positive cytology — leptomeningeal disease; elevated protein — inflammation
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: Mass lesion on imaging (perform MRI first); coagulopathy; anticoagulation; skin infection at LP site

Essential/First-line.timing: **First-line for ALL tinnitus patients**; pure tone audiometry, speech discrimination, tympanometry; identifies type and degree of hearing loss; essential for determining etiology
Essential/First-line.target: Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) — cochlear vs. retrocochlear; conductive hearing loss (CHL) — middle ear pathology; asymmetric SNHL — MRI for vestibular schwannoma; normal — reassuring but does not exclude pathology

Essential/First-line.item: **MRI brain and IACs (internal auditory canals) with gadolinium** (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: **Essential if**: Unilateral or asymmetric tinnitus; unilateral or asymmetric SNHL; pulsatile tinnitus (to evaluate for vascular malformation or CPA mass); focal neurological deficits; **Gold standard** for vestibular schwannoma, CPA tumors, meningioma, demyelination
Essential/First-line.target: Vestibular schwannoma (enhancing mass in IAC/CPA); meningioma; dural AVF; brainstem lesion; MS plaque; cholesteatoma; leptomeningeal disease
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia; GFR <30 (gadolinium contraindication)

Essential/First-line.timing: **Bedside exam for ALL patients**; evaluate for cerumen impaction, tympanic membrane perforation, middle ear effusion, glomus tumor (visible as red/blue mass behind TM), cholesteatoma
Essential/First-line.target: Cerumen impaction — removal; retrotympanic mass (glomus tumor, aberrant carotid, high jugular bulb); TM perforation; middle ear effusion

Essential/First-line.timing: **Critical for pulsatile tinnitus**; listen over mastoid, periauricular, orbits, and neck for bruit; detect objective tinnitus from vascular lesion (dural AVF, carotid stenosis, glomus tumor)
Essential/First-line.target: Bruit present — vascular imaging (MRA/CTA); no bruit does NOT exclude vascular cause

Extended.timing: **Pulsatile tinnitus workup**; evaluates for dural AVF, arterial stenosis/dissection, fibromuscular dysplasia, vertebral/carotid stenosis, aneurysm; use CTA if MRA not available
Extended.target: Dural AVF (early venous filling); carotid stenosis; carotid/vertebral dissection; fibromuscular dysplasia; aneurysm; aberrant vasculature
Extended.contraindications: MRA: same as MRI; CTA (CPT 70496/70498): contrast allergy, renal impairment

Extended.timing: **Evaluate bony anatomy**; superior semicircular canal dehiscence (can cause pulsatile tinnitus); glomus jugulare/tympanicum; otosclerosis; cholesteatoma; aberrant carotid artery; high jugular bulb; tegmen defect
Extended.target: Glomus tumor (permeative bone destruction); canal dehiscence; otosclerosis; temporal bone fracture; aberrant carotid

Extended.timing: Alternative or complement to MRA for pulsatile tinnitus; better spatial resolution for some vascular lesions; faster acquisition in ED; evaluates for dural AVF, carotid stenosis, dissection, glomus tumor
Extended.target: Dural AVF; stenosis; dissection; glomus tumor vascularity; fibromuscular dysplasia

Extended.timing: Non-invasive screening for carotid stenosis if pulsatile tinnitus; can detect FMD in some cases; identifies high-flow states
Extended.target: Carotid stenosis; plaque; FMD (string of beads); flow abnormalities

Extended.timing: **Evaluate for papilledema** if pulsatile tinnitus (IIH); bilateral papilledema in young obese female with pulsatile tinnitus — IIH until proven otherwise
Extended.target: Papilledema — measure opening pressure (LP); IIH; venous sinus thrombosis

Extended.timing: If IIH or cerebral venous sinus thrombosis suspected; evaluates venous sinus patency; transverse sinus stenosis (common in IIH and common cause of pulsatile tinnitus)
Extended.target: Venous sinus thrombosis; transverse sinus stenosis (bilateral or unilateral); venous outflow obstruction

Rare/Advanced.timing: **Gold standard for dural AVF**; obtain when MRA/CTA suggestive but inconclusive; preoperative planning for AVF embolization or glomus tumor; evaluates venous drainage patterns
Rare/Advanced.target: Dural AVF (early venous filling, fistula site, venous drainage pattern); glomus tumor blood supply; vascular anatomy for embolization planning
Rare/Advanced.contraindications: Invasive (stroke risk ~0.5%); contrast allergy; renal impairment; coagulopathy

Rare/Advanced.timing: If vestibular symptoms accompany tinnitus; evaluate vestibular function; caloric testing for unilateral vestibular hypofunction
Rare/Advanced.target: Unilateral weakness (peripheral vestibular lesion); central patterns

Rare/Advanced.timing: If retrocochlear pathology suspected and MRI contraindicated; screening for vestibular schwannoma when MRI not possible; interaural latency differences
Rare/Advanced.target: Prolonged wave I-III or I-V interpeak latency (retrocochlear lesion); absent waves
Rare/Advanced.contraindications: Requires patient cooperation; less sensitive than MRI

Rare/Advanced.timing: If superior semicircular canal dehiscence suspected (pulsatile tinnitus, autophony, bone conduction hyperacusis); tests saccule/utricle
Rare/Advanced.target: Reduced threshold on cVEMP/oVEMP — canal dehiscence

Rare/Advanced.timing: Assess outer hair cell function; normal OAEs with abnormal audiogram suggest retrocochlear pathology; helps differentiate cochlear vs. neural
Rare/Advanced.target: Present OAEs with abnormal ABR — auditory neuropathy/retrocochlear; absent OAEs — cochlear damage

Rare/Advanced.timing: Specialized for aberrant carotid artery, dehiscent jugular bulb, or persistent stapedial artery causing pulsatile tinnitus
Rare/Advanced.target: Aberrant vascular anatomy; dehiscent jugular bulb; persistent stapedial artery

dosing.instructions: **Priority is identifying and treating the underlying cause**: Cerumen removal (impaction); antibiotics for otitis; correct anemia; treat hyperthyroidism; discontinue ototoxic medications; manage IIH; refer for vascular intervention (dural AVF embolization, carotid endarterectomy)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Tinnitus is a symptom, not a diagnosis; treatment of underlying cause resolves tinnitus completely in many cases

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: All tinnitus patients on ototoxic drugs

dosing.instructions: **Review medication list**: High-dose aspirin (>2g/day), aminoglycosides, loop diuretics (furosemide), cisplatin, quinine, vancomycin, erythromycin; reduce dose or substitute when possible

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: When medication is essential and no alternative exists
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Ototoxic medications are a common reversible cause; [Cianfrone et al. (2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21796866/): medication review is first step

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus

doseOptions.orderSentence: **IV dexamethasone** (sudden SNHL with tinnitus) 10 mg IV

dosing.instructions: **Sudden SNHL is otologic emergency**: Dexamethasone 10 mg IV then transition to oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) x 14 days with taper; OR methylprednisolone 48 mg daily x 14 days; start within 72 hours for best outcomes; ENT urgent referral
dosing.orderSentence: **IV dexamethasone** (sudden SNHL with tinnitus) 10 mg IV

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Active infection (relative); uncontrolled diabetes; GI bleed
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Blood glucose monitoring every 6 hours while on steroids; [Chandrasekhar et al. (2019)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33082670/): AAO-HNS guideline recommends steroids within 2 weeks of sudden SNHL onset; earlier is better

dosing.instructions: Acetazolamide 250-500 mg PO BID, titrate up to 1g BID as tolerated; monitor electrolytes; reduces CSF production; can dramatically improve pulsatile tinnitus in IIH

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Sulfa allergy; hepatic insufficiency; hypokalemia; metabolic acidosis
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Electrolytes (potassium, bicarbonate) weekly x 4 weeks, then monthly; renal function; paresthesias (common, benign); [NORDIC Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension Study Group (2014)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24687293/): acetazolamide effective for IIH

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Non-pulsatile tinnitus with distress, anxiety, insomnia, or functional impairment

dosing.instructions: **First-line evidence-based therapy**: 8-20 sessions of CBT adapted for tinnitus; addresses catastrophic thinking, hypervigilance, emotional response to tinnitus; reduces tinnitus distress, improves sleep and function; does NOT eliminate tinnitus but reduces impact

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Track TFI/THI scores every 4-6 sessions; [Cima et al. (2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23316517/): RCT demonstrated CBT significantly reduces tinnitus severity and improves quality of life; [Cochrane review (2020)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33264419/): CBT is most evidence-supported therapy

dosing.instructions: **Options**: Background sound enrichment (fan, white noise, nature sounds); ear-level sound generators; combination hearing aid + sound generator; Notch therapy (tailor-made notched music); smartphone apps (e.g., Oto, ReSound Relief); avoid silence

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Partial or complete masking reduces tinnitus perception; [Hobson et al. (2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24294311/): Cochrane review — limited evidence but widely recommended as adjunct; safe and well tolerated

dosing.instructions: **Combined counseling + sound therapy**: Directive counseling (neurophysiological model) + low-level broadband sound generators worn 6-8h/day; goal is habituation (tinnitus perceived but not bothersome); requires 12-24 months

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Requires patient commitment and trained provider
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Clinical improvement in 70-80%; [Jastreboff & Jastreboff (2000)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10768108/): established protocol; evidence is moderate

dosing.instructions: **If hearing loss present**: Amplification reduces tinnitus perception by enriching auditory input; modern hearing aids include tinnitus masking programs; bilateral fitting preferred for bilateral loss; trial period recommended

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Profound hearing loss (cochlear implant evaluation instead)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: [Shekhawat et al. (2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24431511/): hearing aids improve tinnitus in majority of patients with hearing loss; offer to all eligible patients

dosing.instructions: Mindfulness-based approach; acceptance of tinnitus rather than control; values-driven action; emerging evidence supports efficacy

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Track TFI/THI scores; [Westin et al. (2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21864830/): ACT comparable to CBT for tinnitus distress reduction

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Tinnitus with comorbid insomnia, depression, or anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg QHS, titrate by 10 mg every 1-2 weeks to 50 mg; low-dose TCA; reduces tinnitus perception in subset of patients; stronger evidence for comorbid conditions

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Cardiac arrhythmia; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly (anticholinergic risk)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: ECG at baseline; anticholinergic side effects; limited direct evidence for tinnitus; [Sullivan et al. (1993)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8215728/): modest benefit in severe tinnitus

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Tinnitus with comorbid depression; alternative to amitriptyline with fewer anticholinergic effects

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg QHS, titrate to 50-75 mg; less sedating than amitriptyline

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly (anticholinergic risk)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: ECG at baseline if dose >75 mg; monitor for anticholinergic side effects; [Sullivan et al. (1993)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8215728/): RCT showed nortriptyline reduced tinnitus loudness and depression scores

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg at bedtime; improves sleep in tinnitus patients; modest direct effect on tinnitus

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: [Hurtuk et al. (2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21859051/): melatonin improved tinnitus scores in patients with sleep disturbance; safe; low side effect profile

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg daily, titrate to 100-200 mg; SSRI; treats comorbid anxiety and depression that amplify tinnitus distress

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Monitor mood; GI side effects initially; [Zoger et al. (2006)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16844885/): sertraline reduced tinnitus severity in patients with anxiety/depression

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Tinnitus associated with acoustic trauma or comorbid neuropathic pain

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg QHS, titrate by 300 mg every 3-5 days to 300-600 mg TID; limited evidence for tinnitus alone; helps subset with noise-induced tinnitus

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: [Bauer & Brozoski (2006)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16413413/): some benefit in trauma-related tinnitus; negative in other populations; use if comorbid neuropathic pain

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Dural arteriovenous fistula confirmed on angiography

dosing.instructions: **Endovascular embolization is primary treatment**; transarterial or transvenous approach; goal is complete obliteration of fistula; staged procedures if needed; curative in majority; high-risk AVFs (cortical venous drainage, Cognard type IIb-V) require urgent treatment

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: [Awad et al. (1990)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2079660/): endovascular embolization is effective; complete obliteration cures pulsatile tinnitus; monitor for recurrence

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Carotid stenosis causing pulsatile tinnitus (typically >70% stenosis)

dosing.instructions: Per stroke prevention guidelines; tinnitus resolves after revascularization in many cases; surgical decision based on stenosis degree and stroke risk, not tinnitus alone

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: High surgical risk; complete occlusion (endarterectomy futile)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Standard carotid intervention monitoring; tinnitus resolution variable; treat per vascular guidelines

dosing.instructions: Acetazolamide 250-500 mg PO BID, titrate up to 1g BID as tolerated; first-line medical therapy for IIH; weight loss is critical adjunct; reduces CSF production

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Sulfa allergy; severe hepatic/renal disease; hypokalemia; metabolic acidosis
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Electrolytes (potassium, bicarbonate) weekly x 4 weeks, then monthly; renal function; visual fields every 3-6 months

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: IIH with venous sinus stenosis causing refractory pulsatile tinnitus

dosing.instructions: Stenting of stenotic transverse sinus; emerging procedure for IIH refractory to medical therapy; resolves pulsatile tinnitus and headache in majority; requires pressure gradient >8 mmHg across stenosis

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Venous sinus thrombosis; no gradient across stenosis
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: [Ahmed et al. (2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24293693/): venous sinus stenting improved symptoms in majority of IIH patients; long-term data emerging

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Glomus jugulare or tympanicum causing pulsatile tinnitus

dosing.instructions: Surgical resection (often with preoperative embolization); radiosurgery for poor surgical candidates; observation for small, asymptomatic lesions in elderly; multidisciplinary skull base team

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Major surgery risks (cranial nerve damage, especially CN VII, IX, X, XI); bleeding
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Preoperative embolization reduces intraoperative bleeding; monitor cranial nerve function; hearing preservation when possible

dosing.instructions: 5-10% body weight loss significantly reduces ICP; bariatric surgery referral for BMI >40 or BMI >35 with comorbidities; dietary counseling

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: [Sinclair et al. (2010)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21712910/): weight loss reduces ICP and improves IIH symptoms including pulsatile tinnitus

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Small vestibular schwannoma (<1.5 cm) without significant growth or symptoms

dosing.instructions: **Serial MRI with contrast** every 6-12 months for first 3 years, then annually if stable; majority of small tumors grow <2 mm/year; intervention if growth, hearing deterioration, or new symptoms

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Not appropriate for rapidly growing tumors or large tumors with brainstem compression
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: [Stangerup et al. (2006)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16791048/): majority of small VS show no significant growth; conservative management appropriate for small tumors

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular schwannoma <3 cm; growth on serial MRI; patient preference or poor surgical candidate

dosing.instructions: Tumor margin dose typically 12-13 Gy; high tumor control rate (>90%); hearing preservation 50-70% at 5 years; tinnitus outcome variable (improve, stabilize, or worsen)

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Very large tumors (>3 cm); brainstem compression requiring decompression
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: [Lunsford et al. (2005)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16339521/): long-term tumor control >97%; hearing preservation achievable

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Large vestibular schwannoma (>2.5-3 cm); brainstem compression; cystic tumors; failed radiosurgery

dosing.instructions: Approaches: retrosigmoid (hearing preservation), translabyrinthine (no hearing preservation), middle fossa (small tumors, hearing preservation); choice depends on tumor size, hearing status, and surgeon expertise

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Poor surgical candidate; small non-growing tumor
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Intraoperative facial nerve monitoring (CN VII); postoperative cranial nerve assessment; MRI surveillance for recurrence

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Ototoxic; dose-dependent cochlear and vestibular toxicity; can worsen tinnitus permanently

dosing.instructions: AVOID in tinnitus patients unless no alternative exists; if essential, use once-daily dosing to reduce ototoxicity

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Tinnitus or pre-existing hearing loss (relative); renal impairment increases risk
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Drug levels (trough <1 for gentamicin); serial audiometry if prolonged course

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Dose-dependent tinnitus; reversible with dose reduction; salicylate toxicity

dosing.instructions: AVOID doses >2 g/day; tinnitus usually resolves within 24-48h of dose reduction; low-dose aspirin (81-325 mg) is safe

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Salicylate level if toxicity suspected; reduce dose if tinnitus develops

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Ototoxic, especially IV high-dose or in renal impairment; usually reversible

dosing.instructions: Use lowest effective dose; avoid rapid IV bolus; ethacrynic acid more ototoxic than furosemide

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Pre-existing hearing loss with high doses (relative)
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Monitor hearing; use lowest effective dose; avoid IV bolus

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Dose-dependent irreversible cochlear toxicity; high-frequency SNHL and tinnitus

dosing.instructions: Irreversible ototoxicity; no proven otoprotectant; cisplatin more ototoxic than carboplatin

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Baseline and serial audiometry during treatment; monitor cumulative dose

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Cinchonism (tinnitus, hearing loss, vertigo); usually reversible

dosing.instructions: Reversible ototoxicity; reduce dose if tinnitus develops; hydroxychloroquine lower risk

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Monitor for tinnitus onset; reduce dose if symptoms develop

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Temporary relief but dependence risk; does not address underlying cause; rebound tinnitus on withdrawal

dosing.instructions: Short-term use only if severe acute distress; transition to CBT/SSRI for long-term management; avoid chronic use

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Dependence risk; respiratory depression; elderly (fall risk)
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Limit to 2-4 weeks; plan transition to non-benzodiazepine therapy

Referrals & Consults.item: Classify tinnitus type (pulsatile vs. non-pulsatile) at initial encounter; pulsatile tinnitus requires vascular workup; ask if pulse-synchronous (check radial pulse simultaneously)
Perform otoscopic exam on ALL patients; assess for cerumen impaction, TM abnormality, retrotympanic mass, cholesteatoma; low-cost, high-yield
Audiology referral for comprehensive audiometry; ALL tinnitus patients require audiometry; asymmetric hearing loss triggers MRI
Review ALL medications for ototoxicity; aspirin, NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, chemotherapeutics; discontinue or substitute when possible
Neurology consultation if focal neurological deficits; pulsatile tinnitus with papilledema (IIH); suspected CPA mass; suspected dural AVF; diagnostic uncertainty
ENT / Otolaryngology referral for ALL patients with unilateral tinnitus; hearing loss; failed initial management; hearing aid evaluation; intratympanic therapy
Fundoscopic exam for pulsatile tinnitus to evaluate for papilledema; IIH presents with pulsatile tinnitus + headache + papilledema; tinnitus can be the presenting symptom

Mental health screening (PHQ-9, GAD-7) for ALL tinnitus patients; tinnitus strongly associated with anxiety, depression, insomnia; tinnitus distress correlates more with psychological state than tinnitus loudness
Neurovascular surgery consultation if dural AVF, glomus tumor, or high-grade carotid stenosis identified; multidisciplinary treatment planning
Skull base surgery / neurotology referral if vestibular schwannoma identified; multidisciplinary discussion (observation vs. SRS vs. surgery)

Patient Instructions.item: **Use sound enrichment at all times, especially at bedtime**: Use a fan, white noise machine, nature sounds, or smartphone app (Oto, ReSound Relief); avoid silence as it amplifies tinnitus perception

**Return to ED immediately** if sudden hearing loss in one or both ears, new weakness or numbness, severe new headache, vision changes, or worsening pulsatile tinnitus with headache — these require urgent evaluation

**Protect hearing from noise exposure**: Wear earplugs or noise-cancelling headphones in loud environments (concerts, power tools, machinery); avoid prolonged headphone use at high volumes; noise exposure worsens tinnitus permanently
**Do NOT stop prescribed medications** (aspirin, acetazolamide, antidepressants) without consulting your neurologist; abrupt discontinuation can worsen symptoms or cause withdrawal effects
**Limit caffeine and alcohol** as both can temporarily worsen tinnitus perception; monitor personal triggers and adjust intake accordingly
**Report new symptoms promptly**: New facial weakness or numbness, worsening hearing, new vertigo, or change in tinnitus character (non-pulsatile becoming pulsatile) warrants re-evaluation
**Engage with recommended therapy**: CBT for tinnitus requires 8-20 sessions for full benefit; attend all scheduled appointments; practice techniques between sessions for best outcomes

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Noise protection: Wear hearing protection in all environments >85 dB; use decibel-monitoring smartphone apps; limit headphone use to 60% volume for no more than 60 minutes at a time (60/60 rule)

Stress management: Chronic stress amplifies tinnitus perception; engage in regular mindfulness, meditation, or relaxation exercises; referral to psychologist or CBT therapist for tinnitus-specific coping strategies

Sleep hygiene: Maintain consistent sleep-wake schedule; use sound enrichment at bedtime (white noise, nature sounds); avoid screens 1 hour before bed; melatonin 3-5 mg if persistent insomnia; CBT-I referral for chronic insomnia
Cardiovascular health: Regular moderate-intensity exercise (150 min/week); optimize blood pressure, lipids, glucose; vascular risk factors worsen both pulsatile and non-pulsatile tinnitus
Avoid ototoxic substances: Read medication labels; ask pharmacist about ototoxicity with new prescriptions; avoid prolonged NSAID use; report any new tinnitus to prescribing physician

differential.features: Perceived by patient only; continuous or intermittent ringing, buzzing, hissing; most common type (~85% of tinnitus)
differential.tests: Noise-induced hearing loss, presbycusis, ototoxic medications, Meniere's disease, vestibular schwannoma, idiopathic

differential.features: Perceived by patient only; rhythmic, pulse-synchronous (heartbeat-like); ~5% of tinnitus but HIGH yield for treatable pathology
differential.tests: IIH, dural AVF, carotid stenosis/dissection, transverse sinus stenosis, anemia, hyperthyroidism, glomus tumor

differential.features: Audible to examiner (stethoscope over ear/mastoid); vascular or mechanical source
differential.tests: Dural AVF, glomus tumor, carotid stenosis, aberrant carotid artery, venous hum, arteriovenous malformation

differential.features: Audible clicking/crackling; rare
differential.tests: Palatal myoclonus, stapedial muscle spasm, patulous Eustachian tube, TMJ crepitus

differential.features: Acquired arteriovenous shunt in dural sinuses; most common in transverse-sigmoid sinus region
differential.tests: Unilateral pulsatile tinnitus (most common presentation); cranial bruit possible; risk of intracranial hemorrhage if cortical venous drainage

differential.features: Elevated CSF pressure; often from transverse sinus stenosis
differential.tests: Bilateral pulsatile tinnitus; headache; papilledema; visual obscurations; young obese female; tinnitus is sole presenting symptom in some cases

differential.features: Atherosclerotic narrowing of internal/common carotid
differential.tests: Ipsilateral pulsatile tinnitus; cervical bruit; vascular risk factors; presents with TIA/stroke in some cases

differential.features: Arterial wall dissection; trauma, spontaneous, connective tissue disease
differential.tests: Acute onset pulsatile tinnitus + headache/neck pain; Horner syndrome (carotid); precedes stroke in some cases

differential.features: Glomus jugulare, glomus tympanicum
differential.tests: Pulsatile tinnitus (most common symptom); conductive hearing loss; red/blue mass behind TM (tympanicum); lower cranial nerve palsies (jugulare)

differential.features: Thrombosis of dural venous sinuses
differential.tests: Pulsatile tinnitus; headache; papilledema; seizures; focal deficits; hypercoagulable state

differential.features: Focal narrowing without elevated ICP; common anatomic variant
differential.tests: Unilateral pulsatile tinnitus; incidental finding in some cases; normal opening pressure on LP

differential.features: Non-inflammatory, non-atherosclerotic arteriopathy
differential.tests: Pulsatile tinnitus; young/middle-aged female; involves carotid, vertebral, renal arteries

differential.features: Anemia, pregnancy, thyrotoxicosis, Paget disease
differential.tests: Bilateral pulsatile tinnitus; resolves with treatment of underlying condition

differential.features: Carotid courses through middle ear; congenital
differential.tests: Pulsatile tinnitus; visible retrotympanic pulsating mass; **DO NOT biopsy** — risk of fatal hemorrhage

differential.features: Unilateral tinnitus (most common initial symptom in many cases); progressive unilateral SNHL; facial numbness (CN V); imbalance; facial weakness late
differential.tests: MRI with gadolinium (IACs)

differential.features: Episodic tinnitus + fluctuating hearing loss + aural fullness + vertigo; low-frequency SNHL
differential.tests: Audiometry; clinical criteria

differential.features: Chronic tinnitus following noise exposure; high-frequency SNHL; bilateral; 4 kHz notch on audiogram
differential.tests: Audiometry; history

differential.features: Age-related SNHL; bilateral high-frequency loss; gradual onset tinnitus
differential.tests: Audiometry; age >60

differential.features: Temporal association with medication use; aminoglycosides, cisplatin, high-dose aspirin, loop diuretics
differential.tests: Medication history; serial audiometry

differential.features: Tinnitus with other neurological symptoms; young adult; relapsing-remitting course
differential.tests: MRI brain with gadolinium

differential.features: Low-frequency conductive hearing loss; tinnitus; family history; Carhart notch on audiogram
differential.tests: Audiometry; CT temporal bones

differential.features: Tinnitus modulated by jaw movement, clenching; ipsilateral; TMJ pain/clicking
differential.tests: Clinical exam; dental referral

differential.features: Tinnitus modulated by neck movement; cervical pathology
differential.tests: Cervical exam; imaging if needed

differential.features: Vestibular schwannoma; CPA mass; asymmetric SNHL
differential.tests: MRI with gadolinium (IACs)

differential.features: Vascular pathology (dural AVF, carotid stenosis, IIH, glomus tumor)
differential.tests: MRA/CTA; MRV; DSA if indicated

differential.features: IIH; cerebral venous sinus thrombosis
differential.tests: Urgent MRI/MRV; LP with opening pressure

differential.features: Dural AVF; carotid stenosis
differential.tests: Urgent vascular imaging; DSA

differential.features: Otologic emergency; vascular occlusion; viral cochleitis
differential.tests: Urgent audiometry; steroids within 72h; ENT

differential.features: CPA mass (facial weakness, numbness); brainstem lesion; stroke
differential.tests: Urgent MRI; neurology consultation

differential.features: Vestibular schwannoma; cholesteatoma; retrocochlear pathology
differential.tests: MRI IACs; audiometry

differential.features: Psychiatric emergency; tinnitus is independent risk factor for suicide
differential.tests: Immediate psychiatric evaluation; safety assessment

differential.features: Glomus tumor; aberrant carotid; high jugular bulb; **DO NOT biopsy**
differential.tests: CT temporal bones; MRI; vascular imaging

evidence.recommendation: Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss Practice Guideline

evidence.evidenceLevel: Stepped-care CBT for tinnitus significantly reduced tinnitus-related distress, improved quality of life in randomized controlled trial (n=492)
evidence.source: CBT is the most evidence-supported therapy for tinnitus; first-line for bothersome chronic tinnitus

evidence.evidenceLevel: Systematic review of rTMS for tinnitus; moderate short-term benefit on tinnitus severity; optimal stimulation parameters not established
evidence.source: TMS is promising but not yet standard; reserved for refractory cases in research settings

evidence.evidenceLevel: Natural history of vestibular schwannoma: tinnitus is presenting symptom in ~70% of patients; often precedes hearing loss
evidence.source: Unilateral tinnitus warrants MRI to rule out vestibular schwannoma

evidence.evidenceLevel: Comprehensive review of pulsatile tinnitus etiologies; defined diagnostic algorithm; dural AVF is most common surgically treatable vascular cause
evidence.source: Pulsatile tinnitus requires systematic vascular evaluation; high rate of identifiable and treatable pathology

evidence.evidenceLevel: Gabapentin showed modest benefit for tinnitus related to acoustic trauma in RCT; no benefit in non-trauma tinnitus
evidence.source: Gabapentin helps trauma-related tinnitus but is not effective for non-traumatic tinnitus

evidence.evidenceLevel: Nortriptyline reduced tinnitus loudness and depression in patients with severe tinnitus and comorbid depression
evidence.source: Tricyclic antidepressants benefit tinnitus patients with depression; treat comorbidity

evidence.evidenceLevel: Acetazolamide with diet significantly improved papilledema, visual function, headache, pulsatile tinnitus, and quality of life in IIH (n=165)
evidence.source: Acetazolamide is first-line medical therapy for IIH; pulsatile tinnitus improves with ICP reduction

evidence.evidenceLevel: AAO-HNS guideline for sudden SNHL: steroids recommended within 2 weeks; intratympanic salvage if systemic fails; MRI to rule out retrocochlear
evidence.source: Standard of care for sudden hearing loss with tinnitus; early treatment improves outcomes
Most sensitive to treatment change; validated; tracks longitudinal response
Widely used; good test-retest reliability; validated in multiple languages
Quick; useful for serial tracking; less comprehensive

monitoring.action: Papilledema — urgent MRI/MRV/LP; focal deficits — STAT MRI; cranial bruit — vascular imaging
Hypertension — manage per guidelines; tachycardia — evaluate thyroid, anemia
Asymmetry — urgent audiometry; sudden SNHL — start steroids

monitoring.target: Document pulsatile vs. non-pulsatile; unilateral vs. bilateral; quality; duration; modulating factors
monitoring.action: Pulsatile — vascular imaging pathway; unilateral — MRI pathway
Glucose >200 — insulin per sliding scale; endocrine consultation if persistent

monitoring.frequency: Baseline, then annually (or sooner if change)
monitoring.action: Progressive hearing loss — repeat MRI; ENT; evaluate ototoxicity
Worsening — adjust therapy; add CBT; medication adjustment; re-evaluate etiology

monitoring.frequency: 6 months, 12 months, then annually x 5 years
monitoring.action: Growth >2 mm/year — SRS or surgery discussion
Visual field loss — escalate IIH treatment (increase acetazolamide, stent/shunt referral)
Worsening — mental health referral; SSRI/CBT; safety plan if suicidal ideation
New ototoxic medication — discuss alternatives; baseline audiometry before starting
Hypokalemia — supplement; metabolic acidosis — dose reduction; renal impairment — discontinue

disposition.criteria: Hemorrhagic complication of dural AVF (intracranial hemorrhage); acute stroke from carotid dissection; severe IIH with visual loss requiring emergent intervention

Sudden sensorineural hearing loss requiring IV steroids and monitoring; newly diagnosed cerebral venous sinus thrombosis requiring anticoagulation initiation; newly diagnosed dural AVF requiring observation and planning for intervention; IIH with significant papilledema requiring serial visual field assessments and LP
Diagnostic uncertainty requiring urgent imaging (MRI/MRA not available as outpatient in timely fashion); intractable symptoms requiring symptomatic management

disposition.disposition: Dangerous etiologies excluded or identified and managed
disposition.criteria: Vascular causes (dural AVF, carotid stenosis) either excluded or treatment plan in place; CPA mass excluded or identified with management plan; IIH diagnosed and treatment initiated
No active sudden SNHL requiring emergent steroids; audiometry completed or scheduled
Audiology within 2-4 weeks; ENT/neurology as indicated; mental health if needed
No suicidal ideation (screen all patients); crisis resources provided if needed

Tinnitus explained (benign in most cases); sound enrichment strategies discussed; avoid silence; hearing protection for noise exposure; when to return (sudden hearing loss, new neurological symptoms, severe distress)
Tinnitus with comorbid anxiety or depression
